div1.p: Carter discusses the accounts of Carroll, Gorgas, and Agramonte regarding Lazear's death.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Albert E. Truby, March 4, 1922
div1.opener:
FROM GEN. ALBERT E. TRUBY
Will have to direct this after I reach Wash'n
(1)
My dear Col. Truby:
div1.p:
I could not find my notes the
evening you were at my quarters
This is the transcript from them.

Record-shows. C. “was bitten on Aug 27
2. P. M, by the following mosquitoes
C. fasciatus” viz
1- wh had bitten a y. f. patient 6 days before

1 " " " " " " " 2 " "
became sick, Aug 30 or 31”“Had been
in a foul autopsy room - of y. f-
on Aug 24 - in late afternoon-”

Carroll states - in his Galveston address
“Lazear made a number of unsuccess-
ful
2.
unsuccessful attempts with mosqui-
toes appling them one or several days after
biting” (the y. f. patient I presume) “as
Finlay had done: one to himself
10 days after biting.” I reminded
Lazear that I was ready & he at last
applied to my arm an insect
that had bitten a patient with a
severe attack 12 days previously”

Obviously neither of these is
at all compatible with Agra-
monte's statement.

For Lazear. “On september 13”
Reed (page 68) - “ L. was bitten by a mos,
quito - (Culex, species undetermined)
while
3
While at Las Animas Hospital”
Developoped fever Sept, 18: 8 P. M,
Carrol - says - same Galveston Address
“So little attention did he” (Lazear)
“So little importance did he attach
to the mosquito biting him at the
y. f. hospital that he made no note
of it & only related the circumstance
to me when he was taken sick
5 days later”-

Mrs Gorgas has a letter from Gorgas
written just after either during
L's illness: or just after his death
in which he states. “He says” He
4
told me that he saw a mosqui-
(tells me)
to, which he believes to have been
the one they are investigating, on
has hand when he was in Las
Animas & he let him bite as
long as he wanted to.

I don't put this in quotation marks
because I have not the letter before
me - but I am positive - of the expres-
sion. “he told me”, or “he tells
me” meaning that it was first
hand information from Lazear, given when
G. was attending him while sick.

I think then - taking the state-
ments of Carroll & Gorgas - the last
especially - that the accepted account
of
FROM GEN. ALBERT E. TRUBY
C1
B3
5
Lazear's infection is correct.
& that he was not infected intention-
ally as an experiment.

Reed might have felt as he said
about the insurance - but I don't
think Carroll would have said
that L. told him “told me.” had he
not done so. He might have simply
related the fact occurrence as a
fact, without bringing a direct
falsehood in it. It is more improba-
ble - as it had been more unneces-
sary - for Gorgas to have accredit-
ed L. with the same statement
unless he had made it.

In both
FROM GEN. ALBERT E. TRUBY
C1
B3
6
both cases the statement is
alleged to have been made
in the beginning - or about the
beginning - of L.'s illness, at
which time there would have
been, I judge, no special reason
to believe he was going to die

I will try to get hold of Lazear's
note book - but unless I find some
other evidence, my opinion is
as above
div1.closer:
Very truly yrs H. R. Carter
Aboard North Bound Train S. R. R
March 4/22
